    # produce a legend with the unique colors from the scatter
    handles = [plt.Line2D([],[], ls="", marker="o", color=c) for c in colors]

answers.body_markdown:
The `context:` option in the `docker-compose.yml` matches the path option to `docker build`, except that `docker build` seems to strip off a file prefix if it matches the build context directory.  If you're manually running

<!-- language: lang-sh -->

    docker build my-server/ --file=my-server/dev.Dockerfile
    #               ^^^                          ^^^
    #             context                     dockerfile

then you need to change the `docker-compose.yml` to match

<!-- language: lang-yaml -->

    build:
      dockerfile: dev.Dockerfile
      context: my-server

All paths in the `Dockerfile` are relative to the context directory, so given the files you show, this would correspond to a filesystem structure like

<!-- language: none -->

    docker-compose.yml
    my-server/
    +-- go.mod
    +-- go.sum
    +-- dev.Dockerfile

items.body_markdown:
`PipeReader.ReadAsync` returns a `ReadResult` object, which in turn contains a `Buffer` property that returns a `ReadOnlySequence<byte>` object.

This data would be used to parse messages from a device, every message has a header that would be matched against the bytes in the Buffer to know where the message starts and what type to create to parse the message itself.

Problem is it doesn't seem there is any good method to do that from a `ReadOnlySequence`, and there's not much information on it around.

 * It is possible to enumerate the bytes (it has a `GetEnumerator`), but after having done that I would have to manually keep track of the bytes I used to know the position in the Buffer...?
 * There's also a `PositionOf` extension, but it finds the position of a single byte, so it doesn't really seem a great advantage over checking every byte in a loop.

Is there an extension method I'm missing? Is it entirely done in another way?
items.title: Find byte[] in PipeReader

I just tested logic app with template parameters. 

I used the default example for [developing logic app with visual studio][1]. 

I’ve parameterized both the base URL for the RSS feed and the mail to value. The steps are as follows – 

1.	Declare template parameter. The defaultValue is not mandatory.
[![Step1][2]][2]
2.	Replace the strings inside the fields by replacing with the parameter call.
[![Step2][3]][3]
3.	Then you can also override these parameters in parameter file as well.
 [![Step3][4]][4]
4.	You can also override the value of parameter in CD pipeline
[![enter image description here][5]][5]

> The precedence of the values are `“LogicApp.json” <
> “LogicApp.parameters.json” < “override in CD pipeline”`.

For this example you can see that I used “google.com” as default base URL. But I override it in parameter files. Also I have three different email address in different files. So the email address was used as presented in CD pipeline overriding both the default declaration and the parameter file. 

But the base url is used as mentioned in the parameter file. So if you have different stage/task for deploying the logic app to development and production environment, you can use either way.

This line denotes list comprehension. Here you are running a for loop for `range(3)`, so it stops at `i=2` iterating as `0`, `1` and then `2`. `len(vec)-1 -i` produces `2`, `1`, `0`. You are accessing `vec[0][2]`, `vec[1][1]`, and then `vec[2][0]` through the for loop.

I'll explain your code step by step :

    # This creates a 2D matrix (a nested list as we say in Python).
    vec = [[11, 21, 31],
           [42, 52, 62],
           [73, 83, 93]]
    
    # To obtain all the elements of the counterdiagonal in the 2D matrix, we iterate with inital value of i set to `0`, then,   
    # Possible values for i varaible will be 0,1,2. 
    # Hence, vec[i][len(vec)-1-i] will select following elements:
    # vec[0][2] = 31
    # vec[1][1] = 52
    # vec[2][0] = 73
    # These elements will then be stored in a new list named var. Hence when you print var, you'll get : 
    var=[vec[i][len(vec)-1-i] for i in range(len(vec))]
    # Output : [31, 52, 73]

answers.body_markdown:
>why the code stop to iterate to i = 2 ? ( I saw in debug mode, but it's still not clear to me)

```
for i in range(len(vec))
```
What is `len(vec)`? `vec` is a list of lists. `len` gets only the outermost length. In this case, `3`. 

Try `print(list(range(3))` to see what values of `i` you'll get. (Explanation: `range` upper bound is exclusive, so it will never get to 3.)

This ensures `vec[i]` never gets out of range.

>Then what exactly does it take into "len(vec)-1 -i ? I know that len(vec) -1 is final of my list, but why -i?

```
vec[i][len(vec)-1-i]
```

`vec[i]` fetches the current sub-list.

`len(vec)` is length of the outer list (3), `len(vec)-1` is the index of the last element, `i` goes from 0 to `len(vec)-1` (inclusive)

Let's analyse what values will `len(vec)-1-i` get for each i:

- i=0 => 2
- i=1 => 1
- i=2 => 0

We're basically "going back" with the index.

So we're getting `vec[0][2]`, `vec[1][1]`, `vec[2][0]`. That is, diagonal of the `vec`, from upper right to lower left.

I have a DB with hotel daily room offers, one document per combination of hotel, day and room. 

I use an index per month, kind of `offers_201910`, so indexes about old months can be dropped later, and I would like that all the offers regarding the same hotel be in the same shard, since they are aggregated together often. Also this way, in case a shard fail, I just do not get wrong results about the hotels there, I just do not get results about them at all.

I have two options when thinking about sharding:

### Elasticsearch sharding
 At the time of indexing I can provide a `routing=<hotel_id>`, so offers about the same hotel are grouped into the same shard. At the time of querying, I just query the hotel and ES does the magic of finding them. **The problem is that I cannot change the shard count later on.**

### Manual sharding
I can create many indexes for the same month, with a letter at the end, that would be my manually created shard. Eg: `offers_201910a`,  `offers_201910b`,  `offers_201910c` and so on. Then at the time of querying, I indicate that I want to query over index wildcard `offers_201910*`, and it should work AFAIK. The benefit is that I have control to add more of those manual-shards and make new hotels use them instead of the former ones. 

----

According to `Elasticsearch the definitive guide", it is the same querying an index with 50 shards, that 50 indexes with 1 shard each.

Is there anything wrong with the manual sharding approach? Does it make sense?

answers.body_markdown:
I think the correct structure would be `LoginComponent` inside the `declarations` array of the `PagesModule`, and the `PagesModule` inside the `imports` array of the `AppModule`.

It completely depends on the architecture of your application though. You might be lazy loading the `PagesModule`, for example, which would mean it should not be imported, or you might be using the `LoginComponent` outside of the `PagesModule`, which would mean it should be exported out of it.

In Angular, every component must be declared inside a module, and only one module. Modules can be imported as many times as you want in different modules though, and because modules can also export components, you can use those components throughout the application. `AppModule` is by default the root module of an Angular application. Any other module is what is commonly referred to as a "feature module". I'd read carefully the [Angular Docs][1]


  [1]: https://angular.io/guide/ngmodules

    SELECT
        DateA,
        DateB,
        TRUNC(DateA) - TRUNC(DateB) AS diff
    FROM yourTable;

[![screen capture from demo][1]][1]

[<h2>Demo</h2>][2]


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/k2Dge.png

answers.title: How to cast full Timestamp into Date in Oracle?

answers.body_markdown:
A `DATE` data type always has year, month, day, hour, minute and second components.

A `TIMESTAMP` data type always has the same components plus can have fractional seconds and time zone information.

So if you `CAST` from `TIMESTAMP` to `DATE` all you are doing is discarding the fractional seconds and time zone information; you will still have the hours, minutes and seconds.

If you just want year/month/day components then don't use `CAST`; instead, use `TRUNC` which will return a `DATE` data type truncate back to midnight of the same day:

```sql
SELECT TimestampA,
       TimestampB,
       TRUNC( TimestampA ) - TRUNC( TimestampB ) AS days_difference
FROM   your_table
```

If you have time zone information then convert the values to a common time zone (typically UTC) and then truncate them:

**Oracle Setup**:

```sql
CREATE TABLE your_table ( timestampA, timestampB ) AS
SELECT TIMESTAMP '2019-09-25 07:00:00.000000000 +07:00', TIMESTAMP '2019-09-27 03:00:00.000000000 +04:00' FROM DUAL
```

**Query**:

```
SELECT TimestampA,
       TimestampB,
       TimestampA AT TIME ZONE 'UTC' AS utcA,
       TimestampB AT TIME ZONE 'UTC' AS utcB,
       TRUNC( TimestampA AT TIME ZONE 'UTC' ) - TRUNC( TimestampB AT TIME ZONE 'UTC' ) AS days_difference
FROM   your_table
```

outputs:

> <pre>
> TIMESTAMPA                     | TIMESTAMPB                     | UTCA                        | UTCB                        | DAYS_DIFFERENCE
> :----------------------------- | :----------------------------- | :-------------------------- | :-------------------------- | --------------:
> 2019-09-25T07:00:00.000 +07:00 | 2019-09-27T03:00:00.000 +04:00 | 2019-09-25T00:00:00.000 UTC | 2019-09-26T23:00:00.000 UTC |              -1
> </pre>

*db<>fiddle [here](https://dbfiddle.uk/?rdbms=oracle_11.2&fiddle=1fd9fe19f7efcafee33f8043639b32ab)*
answers.title: How to cast full Timestamp into Date in Oracle?

Your query is off, and is mixing the old-school implicit join syntax with the modern (preferred) join syntax.  Here is the version you should be using:

    SELECT new com.demo.DTO.resultsDTO(a.id)
    FROM A a
    INNER JOIN B b
        ON a.id = b.id
    WHERE
        b.isDeleted = false AND
        b.name = ?1;

Your updated Java code:

    @Query("SELECT new com.demo.DTO.resultsDTO(a.id) FROM A a INNER JOIN B b ON a.id = b.id WHERE b.isDeleted = false AND b.name = ?1")

answers.body_markdown:
The argument to `ResponseAddBody` is an offset to the serialized byte vector (the `int` in your error), not the `bytes` object directly. This needs to be serialized *before* the table.

So, right after you create `builder`, call `builder.CreateByteVector(my_bytes)`, the result of which you pass to `ResponseAddBody` later.

Alternatively, here's how to create any vector manually (select Python, search for `inventory`): https://google.github.io/flatbuffers/flatbuffers_guide_tutorial.html

Note, you appear to be using 2 serialization systems, pickle and FlatBuffers. You'd be better off encoding the picked data directly in FlatBuffers, using e.g. `table Foo { a:int }` instead of your dict, or if it has to be an open-ended dict, a vector of `table KeyValue { key:string; value:int; }` or similar. Or a union, depending on your use case.

answers.body_markdown:
In your pattern `.+?(?=[^.]+$)` you assert what is directly on the right is 1+ times not a dot followed by the end of the string.

That assertion could be true at multiple places and will also include matching the dot itself. 

For example in `filename2.csv.gz` that will match `filename2.csv.` and `g`

If you want to get the match only of the filename in the example data, you could add the dot in the positive lookahead:

    .+(?=\.[^.]+$)

[Regex demo](https://regex101.com/r/SqY9GY/1)

Or use a capturing group and a match instead of a lookahead:

    (.+)\.[^.]+$

[Regex demo](https://regex101.com/r/2sF0Fj/1) | [Perl demo](https://ideone.com/QNuVaL)

For example

    my $line = "filename1.csv.Z";
    my ($output) = $line =~ m/(.+)\.[^.]+$/;
    print $output;
    
    # filename1.csv

answers.body_markdown:
`check[0]` is a single character -- the character '8'. This means that you call the [`Convert.ToInt32(char)`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.convert.toint32?view=netframework-4.8#System_Convert_ToInt32_System_Char_) overload, which:

>  returns a 32-bit signed integer that represents the UTF-16 encoded code unit of the value argument

`'8'` has the value 56.

`check[0].ToString()` returns a string, and so you call [`Convert.ToInt32(string)`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.convert.toint32?view=netframework-4.8#System_Convert_ToInt32_System_String_), which returns:

> A 32-bit signed integer that is equivalent to the number in value, or 0 (zero) if value is null
answers.title: Convert.ToInt32(string) giving wrong values

answers.body_markdown:
There's nothing wrong here.

Your first call is to [`Convert.ToInt32(char)`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.convert.toint32?view=netframework-4.8#System_Convert_ToInt32_System_Char_) which just promotes the `char` to `int`. The value of `check[0]` is a `char` with a value of 56 - the UTF-16 value of '8'.

Your second call is to [`Convert.ToInt32(string)`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.convert.toint32?view=netframework-4.8#System_Convert_ToInt32_System_String_) which parses the string as a number. The string "8" is parsed to the value 8.

answers.body_markdown:
There are a few ways you can refer to another worksheet in a workbook, and even refer to another workbook.

Refer to another sheet with `Sheets(` or `Worksheets(`. This can take two arguments, either a sheet number `Sheets(1)`, but I find this unreliable as it sometimes is hard to keep track of the proper sheet numbers when adding and removing sheets. The best way is to refer directly by the sheet name: `Sheets("Sheetname")`. Please note there is a [slight difference](https://exceloffthegrid.com/sheets-and-worksheets-in-vba/) in using `Sheets` or `Worksheets`.

As SJR pointed out there is a third way to refer to sheets with the sheet `codename`. The codename is the name of the sheet displayed in your VBA window. You can get the codename of your sheet with `Debug.Print Sheet("name").Codename`. And you can refer directly to this sheet like so `Sheet1.Range("A:A")` etc.

To make sure you refer to the right sheet within the workbook you have open, and prevent yourself from having your VBA run in another workbook you have open at the same time use either `Activeworkbook.Sheets`, which refers to the workbook which is currently active, or `Thisworkbook.Sheets` which refers to the specific workbook the VBA code is in. You can also use `Workbook("Workbook name").sheets`.

[Some further reading for you.](https://corporatefinanceinstitute.com/resources/excel/study/vba-methods/)
answers.title: how to refer to a worksheet in a workbook?

import keras.backend as K

    def myactivation(x):
        #x is the layer's output, shaped as (batch_size, units)

        #each element in the last dimension is a neuron
        n0 = x[:,0:1]
        n1 = x[:,1:2]
        n2 = x[:,2:3]  #each N is shaped as (batch_size, 1)

        #apply the activation to each neuron
        x0 = K.relu(n0)
        x1 = K.tanh(n1)
        x2 = K.sigmoid(n2)

        return K.concatenate([x0,x1,x2], axis=-1) #return to the original shape

answers.body_markdown:
Your example does not really illustrate the parameters' mutual interdependence. As for the conditional aspect, you can embed arbitrary conditions into your function call. So you could have e.g.:
```
(foo (if (something-p) 'a1 'a2)
     (if (something-p) 'b1 'b2))
```
EDIT:
If you're concerned about multiple evaluations of `something-p`, you can always store the value of a single evaluation in a `let` variable like this:
```
(let ((c (something-p)))
  (foo (if c 'a1 'a2)
       (if c 'b1 'b2)))
```
answers.title: lisp: properly calling a function with 2 parameters which depend on each other

answers.body_markdown:
Examples:

Applying a list:

    (apply #'foo
           (if (something-p)
              (list 'a1 'b1)
              (list 'a2 'b2)))

Similar, but with multiple values:

    (multiple-value-call #'foo
      (if (something)
         (values 'a1 'b1)
         (values 'a2 'b2)))

Binding multiple values:

    (multiple-value-bind (a b)
        (if (something)
            (values 'a1 'b1)
            (values 'a2 'b2))
      (foo a b))

Nested `let`:

    (let ((something (something-p)))
      (let ((a (if something 'a1 'b2))
            (b (if something 'b1 'b2)))
        (foo a b)))
answers.title: lisp: properly calling a function with 2 parameters which depend on each other

answers.body_markdown:
The `context:` option in the `docker-compose.yml` matches the path option to `docker build`, except that `docker build` seems to strip off a file prefix if it matches the build context directory.  If you're manually running

<!-- language: lang-sh -->

    docker build my-server/ --file=my-server/dev.Dockerfile
    #               ^^^                          ^^^
    #             context                     dockerfile

then you need to change the `docker-compose.yml` to match

<!-- language: lang-yaml -->

    build:
      dockerfile: dev.Dockerfile
      context: my-server

All paths in the `Dockerfile` are relative to the context directory, so given the files you show, this would correspond to a filesystem structure like

<!-- language: none -->

    docker-compose.yml
    my-server/
    +-- go.mod
    +-- go.sum
    +-- dev.Dockerfile

answers.body_markdown:
var=[vec[i][len(vec)-1-i] for i in range(len(vec))]
This line denotes list comprehension. Here you are running a for loop for `range(3)`, so it stops at `i=2` iterating as `0`, `1` and then `2`. `len(vec)-1 -i` produces `2`, `1`, `0`. You are accessing `vec[0][2]`, `vec[1][1]`, and then `vec[2][0]` through the for loop.
answers.title: Python list comprehension logical into example

answers.body_markdown:
I'll explain your code step by step :

    # This creates a 2D matrix (a nested list as we say in Python).
    vec = [[11, 21, 31],
           [42, 52, 62],
           [73, 83, 93]]
    
    # To obtain all the elements of the counterdiagonal in the 2D matrix, we iterate with inital value of i set to `0`, then,   
    # Possible values for i varaible will be 0,1,2. 
    # Hence, vec[i][len(vec)-1-i] will select following elements:
    # vec[0][2] = 31
    # vec[1][1] = 52
    # vec[2][0] = 73
    # These elements will then be stored in a new list named var. Hence when you print var, you'll get : 
    var=[vec[i][len(vec)-1-i] for i in range(len(vec))]
    # Output : [31, 52, 73]
    print(var)
answers.title: Python list comprehension logical into example

answers.body_markdown:
>why the code stop to iterate to i = 2 ? ( I saw in debug mode, but it's still not clear to me)

```
for i in range(len(vec))
```
What is `len(vec)`? `vec` is a list of lists. `len` gets only the outermost length. In this case, `3`. 

Try `print(list(range(3))` to see what values of `i` you'll get. (Explanation: `range` upper bound is exclusive, so it will never get to 3.)

This ensures `vec[i]` never gets out of range.

>Then what exactly does it take into "len(vec)-1 -i ? I know that len(vec) -1 is final of my list, but why -i?

```
vec[i][len(vec)-1-i]
```

`vec[i]` fetches the current sub-list.

`len(vec)` is length of the outer list (3), `len(vec)-1` is the index of the last element, `i` goes from 0 to `len(vec)-1` (inclusive)

Let's analyse what values will `len(vec)-1-i` get for each i:

- i=0 => 2
- i=1 => 1
- i=2 => 0

We're basically "going back" with the index.

So we're getting `vec[0][2]`, `vec[1][1]`, `vec[2][0]`. That is, diagonal of the `vec`, from upper right to lower left.

I have a DB with hotel daily room offers, one document per combination of hotel, day and room. 

I use an index per month, kind of `offers_201910`, so indexes about old months can be dropped later, and I would like that all the offers regarding the same hotel be in the same shard, since they are aggregated together often. Also this way, in case a shard fail, I just do not get wrong results about the hotels there, I just do not get results about them at all.

I have two options when thinking about sharding:

### Elasticsearch sharding
 At the time of indexing I can provide a `routing=<hotel_id>`, so offers about the same hotel are grouped into the same shard. At the time of querying, I just query the hotel and ES does the magic of finding them. **The problem is that I cannot change the shard count later on.**

### Manual sharding
I can create many indexes for the same month, with a letter at the end, that would be my manually created shard. Eg: `offers_201910a`,  `offers_201910b`,  `offers_201910c` and so on. Then at the time of querying, I indicate that I want to query over index wildcard `offers_201910*`, and it should work AFAIK. The benefit is that I have control to add more of those manual-shards and make new hotels use them instead of the former ones. 

----

According to `Elasticsearch the definitive guide", it is the same querying an index with 50 shards, that 50 indexes with 1 shard each.

Is there anything wrong with the manual sharding approach? Does it make sense?

answers.body_markdown:
I think the correct structure would be `LoginComponent` inside the `declarations` array of the `PagesModule`, and the `PagesModule` inside the `imports` array of the `AppModule`.

It completely depends on the architecture of your application though. You might be lazy loading the `PagesModule`, for example, which would mean it should not be imported, or you might be using the `LoginComponent` outside of the `PagesModule`, which would mean it should be exported out of it.

In Angular, every component must be declared inside a module, and only one module. Modules can be imported as many times as you want in different modules though, and because modules can also export components, you can use those components throughout the application. `AppModule` is by default the root module of an Angular application. Any other module is what is commonly referred to as a "feature module". I'd read carefully the [Angular Docs][1]


  [1]: https://angular.io/guide/ngmodules

answers.title: How to cast full Timestamp into Date in Oracle?

answers.body_markdown:
A `DATE` data type always has year, month, day, hour, minute and second components.

A `TIMESTAMP` data type always has the same components plus can have fractional seconds and time zone information.

So if you `CAST` from `TIMESTAMP` to `DATE` all you are doing is discarding the fractional seconds and time zone information; you will still have the hours, minutes and seconds.

If you just want year/month/day components then don't use `CAST`; instead, use `TRUNC` which will return a `DATE` data type truncate back to midnight of the same day:

```sql
SELECT TimestampA,
       TimestampB,
       TRUNC( TimestampA ) - TRUNC( TimestampB ) AS days_difference
FROM   your_table
```

If you have time zone information then convert the values to a common time zone (typically UTC) and then truncate them:

**Oracle Setup**:

```sql
CREATE TABLE your_table ( timestampA, timestampB ) AS
SELECT TIMESTAMP '2019-09-25 07:00:00.000000000 +07:00', TIMESTAMP '2019-09-27 03:00:00.000000000 +04:00' FROM DUAL
```

**Query**:

```
SELECT TimestampA,
       TimestampB,
       TimestampA AT TIME ZONE 'UTC' AS utcA,
       TimestampB AT TIME ZONE 'UTC' AS utcB,
       TRUNC( TimestampA AT TIME ZONE 'UTC' ) - TRUNC( TimestampB AT TIME ZONE 'UTC' ) AS days_difference
FROM   your_table
```

outputs:

> <pre>
> TIMESTAMPA                     | TIMESTAMPB                     | UTCA                        | UTCB                        | DAYS_DIFFERENCE
> :----------------------------- | :----------------------------- | :-------------------------- | :-------------------------- | --------------:
> 2019-09-25T07:00:00.000 +07:00 | 2019-09-27T03:00:00.000 +04:00 | 2019-09-25T00:00:00.000 UTC | 2019-09-26T23:00:00.000 UTC |              -1
> </pre>

*db<>fiddle [here](https://dbfiddle.uk/?rdbms=oracle_11.2&fiddle=1fd9fe19f7efcafee33f8043639b32ab)*
answers.title: How to cast full Timestamp into Date in Oracle?

answers.body_markdown:
Your query is off, and is mixing the old-school implicit join syntax with the modern (preferred) join syntax.  Here is the version you should be using:

    SELECT new com.demo.DTO.resultsDTO(a.id)
    FROM A a
    INNER JOIN B b
        ON a.id = b.id
    WHERE
        b.isDeleted = false AND
        b.name = ?1;

Your updated Java code:

    @Query("SELECT new com.demo.DTO.resultsDTO(a.id) FROM A a INNER JOIN B b ON a.id = b.id WHERE b.isDeleted = false AND b.name = ?1")

answers.body_markdown:
The argument to `ResponseAddBody` is an offset to the serialized byte vector (the `int` in your error), not the `bytes` object directly. This needs to be serialized *before* the table.

So, right after you create `builder`, call `builder.CreateByteVector(my_bytes)`, the result of which you pass to `ResponseAddBody` later.

Alternatively, here's how to create any vector manually (select Python, search for `inventory`): https://google.github.io/flatbuffers/flatbuffers_guide_tutorial.html

Note, you appear to be using 2 serialization systems, pickle and FlatBuffers. You'd be better off encoding the picked data directly in FlatBuffers, using e.g. `table Foo { a:int }` instead of your dict, or if it has to be an open-ended dict, a vector of `table KeyValue { key:string; value:int; }` or similar. Or a union, depending on your use case.

answers.body_markdown:
In your pattern `.+?(?=[^.]+$)` you assert what is directly on the right is 1+ times not a dot followed by the end of the string.

That assertion could be true at multiple places and will also include matching the dot itself. 

For example in `filename2.csv.gz` that will match `filename2.csv.` and `g`

If you want to get the match only of the filename in the example data, you could add the dot in the positive lookahead:

    .+(?=\.[^.]+$)

[Regex demo](https://regex101.com/r/SqY9GY/1)

Or use a capturing group and a match instead of a lookahead:

    (.+)\.[^.]+$

[Regex demo](https://regex101.com/r/2sF0Fj/1) | [Perl demo](https://ideone.com/QNuVaL)

For example

    my $line = "filename1.csv.Z";
    my ($output) = $line =~ m/(.+)\.[^.]+$/;
    print $output;
    
    # filename1.csv

answers.body_markdown:
`check[0]` is a single character -- the character '8'. This means that you call the [`Convert.ToInt32(char)`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.convert.toint32?view=netframework-4.8#System_Convert_ToInt32_System_Char_) overload, which:

>  returns a 32-bit signed integer that represents the UTF-16 encoded code unit of the value argument

`'8'` has the value 56.

`check[0].ToString()` returns a string, and so you call [`Convert.ToInt32(string)`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.convert.toint32?view=netframework-4.8#System_Convert_ToInt32_System_String_), which returns:

> A 32-bit signed integer that is equivalent to the number in value, or 0 (zero) if value is null
answers.title: Convert.ToInt32(string) giving wrong values

answers.body_markdown:
There's nothing wrong here.

Your first call is to [`Convert.ToInt32(char)`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.convert.toint32?view=netframework-4.8#System_Convert_ToInt32_System_Char_) which just promotes the `char` to `int`. The value of `check[0]` is a `char` with a value of 56 - the UTF-16 value of '8'.

Your second call is to [`Convert.ToInt32(string)`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.convert.toint32?view=netframework-4.8#System_Convert_ToInt32_System_String_) which parses the string as a number. The string "8" is parsed to the value 8.

answers.body_markdown:
There are a few ways you can refer to another worksheet in a workbook, and even refer to another workbook.

Refer to another sheet with `Sheets(` or `Worksheets(`. This can take two arguments, either a sheet number `Sheets(1)`, but I find this unreliable as it sometimes is hard to keep track of the proper sheet numbers when adding and removing sheets. The best way is to refer directly by the sheet name: `Sheets("Sheetname")`. Please note there is a [slight difference](https://exceloffthegrid.com/sheets-and-worksheets-in-vba/) in using `Sheets` or `Worksheets`.

As SJR pointed out there is a third way to refer to sheets with the sheet `codename`. The codename is the name of the sheet displayed in your VBA window. You can get the codename of your sheet with `Debug.Print Sheet("name").Codename`. And you can refer directly to this sheet like so `Sheet1.Range("A:A")` etc.

To make sure you refer to the right sheet within the workbook you have open, and prevent yourself from having your VBA run in another workbook you have open at the same time use either `Activeworkbook.Sheets`, which refers to the workbook which is currently active, or `Thisworkbook.Sheets` which refers to the specific workbook the VBA code is in. You can also use `Workbook("Workbook name").sheets`.

[Some further reading for you.](https://corporatefinanceinstitute.com/resources/excel/study/vba-methods/)
